pullRequest.body:
This PR defines the [weak operator topology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_operator_topology) on maps between normed spaces and proves some of its basic properties. It creates a type copy of `E ‚ÜíL[ùïú] F` endowed with the WOT rather than the norm topology.

Along the way, we define several lemmas that are useful for proving properties of a topology that is induced by a bundled hom.

Note: I've defined the global notation `E ‚ÜíWOT[ùïú] F` for the type copy; I don't think this is likely to collide with anything else, but I can make it scoped if this is deemed preferable.

Co-authored-by: Jireh Loreaux <loreaujy@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

> Does `ext` behave well where there are competing `ext` lemmas? If we have both this and `ext_dual_iff.mpr` tagged as `ext`, they would both apply in the Hilbert space case.

I think this was a problem at one point, but I don't think it is any longer. I believe we have resurrected the Lean 3 behavior where the one declared later has priority, so in this case, the inner product version. You could test it though.

:v: dupuisf can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

If you want, you can save completeness for a future PR.

bors d+
This is a first pass. I may have more thoughts about simplifying the proof of the `hasBasis` theorem later. This mostly looks really nice though, thanks!
Thanks @j-loreaux ! Regarding the `HasBasis` proof, note that I mostly cribbed it from `LinearMap.hasBasis_weakBilin`; if you have ideas to simplify it, they probably apply there as well!

If you want, you can save completeness for a future PR.

bors d+

```suggestion
/-- The linear equivalence that sends a continuous linear map to the type copy endowed with the
```
Are you thinking we don't want this to be `@[simp]` because it switches from WOT to CLM and we don't want to break the barrier? If so, you can just resolve this.
Yeah I'm not too sure either whether we want this to be a simp lemma or not. Let's just leave it like this, we can always add the tag later if not having it turns out to be annoying.

Don't we want an actual `@[ext]` lemma too? If so, which one do we want? The `FunLike` one should be copied over in either case. (I think we maybe want `ext_dual_iff.mpr` to be the `@[ext]` lemma for this type).
I agree `ext_dual_iff.mpr` seems like the most natural choice. I've added it as `ext_dual`.

```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
lemma continuous_inducingFn : Continuous (inducingFn ùïú E F) :=
```

```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
lemma continuous_of_dual_apply_continuous {Œ± : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Œ±] {g : Œ± ‚Üí E ‚ÜíWOT[ùïú] F}
```
I think we may also want `ext_inner_iff.mpr` to be an `@[ext]` lemma.
Does `ext` behave well where there are competing `ext` lemmas? If we have both this and `ext_dual_iff.mpr` tagged as `ext`, they would both apply in the Hilbert space case.

I think this was a problem at one point, but I don't think it is any longer. I believe we have resurrected the Lean 3 behavior where the one declared later has priority, so in this case, the inner product version. You could test it though.

I had a quick look at the `ext` code, and it uses a discrimination tree (as I assumed), so the order of declaration probably doesn't matter. However, we can set priorities on ext lemmas so I'll just do that.

My conclusion is that this lemma is missing:
```lean
/-- If a family of seminorms is continuous, then their basis sets are neighborhoods of zero. -/
lemma SeminormFamily.basisSets_mem_nhds {ùïú E Œπ : Type*} [NormedField ùïú]
    [AddCommGroup E] [Module ùïú E] [TopologicalSpace E] (p : SeminormFamily ùïú E Œπ)
    (hp : ‚àÄ i, Continuous (p i)) (U : Set E) (hU : U ‚àà p.basisSets) : U ‚àà ùìù (0 : E) := by
  obtain ‚ü®s, r, hr, rfl‚ü© := p.basisSets_iff.mp hU
  clear hU
  refine Seminorm.ball_mem_nhds ?_ hr
  classical
  induction s using Finset.induction_on with
  | empty => simpa using continuous_zero
  | insert _ hs => simpa using hp _ |>.sup <| hs
```
Note that the induction above is actually a bit necessary because the `empty` case won't hold in general (see `Continuous.finset_sup` for the condition that the codomain of the functions satisfies `OrderBot`).

With this, and the `lift` tactic, using the primed version of `Filter.HasBasis.to_hasBasis`, and various other small cleanups, we get:
```suggestion
lemma hasBasis_seminorms : (ùìù (0 : E ‚ÜíWOT[ùïú] F)).HasBasis (seminormFamily ùïú E F).basisSets id := by
  let p := seminormFamily ùïú E F
  rw [nhds_induced, nhds_pi]
  simp [map_zero, zero_apply]
  have h := Filter.hasBasis_pi (fun _ : (E √ó F‚ãÜ) ‚Ü¶ Metric.nhds_basis_ball (x := 0)) |>.comap
    (inducingFn ùïú E F)
  refine h.to_hasBasis' ?_ ?_
  ¬∑ rintro ‚ü®s, U‚ÇÇ‚ü© ‚ü®hs, hU‚ÇÇ‚ü©
    lift s to Finset (E √ó F‚ãÜ) using hs
    by_cases hU‚ÇÉ : s.Nonempty
    ¬∑ refine ‚ü®(s.sup p).ball 0 <| s.inf' hU‚ÇÉ U‚ÇÇ, p.basisSets_mem _ <| (Finset.lt_inf'_iff _).2 hU‚ÇÇ,
        fun x hx y hy => ?_‚ü©
      simp only [Set.mem_preimage, Set.mem_pi, mem_ball_zero_iff]
      rw [id, Seminorm.mem_ball_zero] at hx
      have hp : p y ‚â§ s.sup p := Finset.le_sup hy
      refine lt_of_le_of_lt (hp x) (lt_of_lt_of_le hx ?_)
      exact Finset.inf'_le _ hy
    ¬∑ rw [Finset.not_nonempty_iff_eq_empty.mp hU‚ÇÉ]
      exact ‚ü®(p 0).ball 0 1, p.basisSets_singleton_mem 0 one_pos, by simp‚ü©
  ¬∑ suffices ‚àÄ U ‚àà p.basisSets, U ‚àà ùìù (0 : E ‚ÜíWOT[ùïú] F) by simpa [nhds_induced, nhds_pi]
    exact p.basisSets_mem_nhds fun ‚ü®x, y‚ü© ‚Ü¶ continuous_dual_apply x y |>.norm
```
Unfortunately, I couldn't avoid that final `suffices` very easily.
Any idea where that new lemma could go? It can't go in `WithSeminorms.lean` because it uses `Continuous.sup`.
Alright, I modified the new lemma to avoid additional imports.

```suggestion
`A : E ‚ÜíWOT[ùïú] F` along filter `l` iff `‚ü™y, (f a) x‚ü´` tends to `‚ü™y, A x‚ü´` along the same filter. -/
```
What about completeness? This should hold at least when `E` and `F` are Hilbert spaces.
Yeah, I think I'll leave that for a future PR!
